title: 114_hr1831
content:
The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2016" establishes the Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking in the executive branch with 15 members appointed by the President and Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking has members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the Minority Leader, and the Majority Leader of the Senate. Each appointee must have expertise in academic research, data analysis, program administration, or data protection. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking appoints members with expertise in academic research, data analysis, program administration, data protection, economics, statistics, program evaluation, data security, confidentiality, or database management. The President selects the chairperson, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives selects the co-chairperson. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking appoints members within 45 days of enactment, with each member serving for the duration of the Commission. Vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without pay but are allowed travel expenses. The Commission's duties include conducting a comprehensive study of data inventory, infrastructure, security, and database management. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking conducts a study on data inventory, infrastructure, security, and database management related to Federal policymaking. It aims to integrate various data sources for program evaluation and research while ensuring data security and privacy. Recommendations will be made to modify data infrastructure to achieve these objectives. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will make recommendations on incorporating outcomes measurement, randomized controlled trials, and impact analysis into program design. They will also consider establishing a clearinghouse for program and survey data, evaluating relevant data for program evaluation and Federal policy-making, and potential linkages between administrative and survey data. The curr_chunk discusses legal and administrative barriers to data linking, data-sharing infrastructure, funding for a clearinghouse, access to data for researchers, privacy protection, and using research results to improve program design. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress detailing its findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation or administrative actions within 15 months of the majority of members being appointed. The report will address incentives for interagency information sharing, data usage notifications, and program effectiveness. The Commission members are appointed under section 3, and the term "administrative data" refers to data held by agencies or contractors collected for non-statistical purposes. The Commission will receive advice from various agencies on matters within their responsibilities. The Commission, comprised of various agencies including the Department of Justice and the Bureau of Labor Statistics, will establish rules of procedure and may hold hearings as needed. Meetings will be scheduled by the chairperson or co-chairperson, with a quorum requirement for conducting business. The Commission, comprised of various agencies, may contract with government and private entities, use the United States mails, and accept gifts. Funding is subject to appropriations and may involve transferring funds from Principal Statistical Agencies. The Commission, funded up to $3,000,000, will receive administrative support from the Bureau of the Census in Suitland, Maryland. No new funding is authorized for this Act, and personnel, including a Director, will be appointed at an established rate of pay. The Director of the Commission will be paid at a rate set by the chairperson and co-chairperson, not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint additional staff and procure services as needed. The Commission will terminate within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The curr_chunk can be summarized as: 
"Speaker of the House of Representatives and Vice President of the United States, also serving as President of the Senate."
